title: GenTool: Enhancing Tool Generalization in Language Models through Zero-to-One and Weak-to-Strong Simulation
author: Jie He (University of Edinburgh), Jennifer Neville (Microsoft Corporation), Mengting Wan (Microsoft Corporation), Longqi Yang (Microsoft Corporation), Hui Liu (Microsoft Corporation), Xiaofeng Xu (Microsoft Corporation), Xia Song (Microsoft Corporation), Jeff Z. Pan (University of Edinburgh), Pei Zhou (Microsoft Corporation)
relevance_why: The framework proposed can enhance tool learning capabilities which could be beneficial for developing more adaptable models in tasks like audio generation, speech processing, or music synthesis where external tools may be integrated.
background: The paper discusses how to improve large language models' ability to generalize tool usage in scenarios where tools are either newly introduced or of varying quality, allowing them to adapt to diverse user queries.
contribution: This paper introduces GenTool, a novel training framework to enhance language models' capacity for tool generalization, achieving significant improvements in tool selection accuracy across various unseen query scenarios.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing methods struggle with overfitting to specific tools and limited context in tool learning, often failing to generalize across new or improved tools.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances model functionality through a two-stage fine-tuning strategy that improves understanding of tool relationships and their selection processes.

key_innovation: Integrates a structured approach to simulate generalization challenges through synthetic data generation, addressing both the introduction of new tools and the upgrade of existing ones.
real_world_impact: The approach could lead to more robust artificial intelligence assistants capable of effectively utilizing a wide range of tools in real-world applications, enhancing user experience significantly.
limitations: The authors acknowledge limitations in model scale, as their experiments focus on models under 8 billion parameters.

new_terms.Zero-to-One Generalization: **Zero-to-One Generalization** refers to the ability of a model to utilize a tool that was not previously available to solve a query when it becomes relevant.
new_terms.Weak-to-Strong Generalization: **Weak-to-Strong Generalization** denotes the model's capacity to differentiate between weaker and stronger versions of tools, selecting the most suitable one for a given task.
